content.title: Persistent Sciatic Artery
content.summary: Persistent sciatic artery (PSA) is a rare congenital vascular anomaly where the embryonic sciatic artery persists as the dominant blood supply to the lower extremity. It is prone to aneurysm formation and may present with limb ischemia.
content.definition: A congenital vascular anomaly in which the embryonic sciatic (axial) artery persists as the primary arterial supply to the lower limb, rather than the normal superficial femoral artery pathway

normal_development.sciatic_artery: Primary arterial supply to leg bud in embryo
normal_development.result: Mature superficial femoral → popliteal → tibial system

PSA_formation.result: Sciatic artery persists as dominant or sole supply to leg

complete_PSA.description: Sciatic artery is dominant; SFA hypoplastic or absent
complete_PSA.course: Leaves pelvis through greater sciatic foramen, runs with sciatic nerve

incomplete_PSA.description: Both sciatic and SFA systems present

epidemiology.aneurysm: Up to 50% develop sciatic artery aneurysm

diagnosis.clinical_suspicion: Popliteal pulse with absent/weak femoral pulse

imaging.CTA: Diagnostic; shows PSA course and associated aneurysm

diagnosis.characteristic_finding: Artery courses through greater sciatic notch alongside nerve

aneurysm_formation.cause: Repetitive trauma (sitting) to exposed artery in buttock

asymptomatic_without_aneurysm.avoid: Femoral access for catheterization may be problematic

asymptomatic_with_aneurysm.rationale: High risk of complications from aneurysm

endovascular.role: Limited; difficult anatomy, movement at hip

clinical_pearls.suspect_when: Popliteal pulse palpable but femoral pulse weak or absent
clinical_pearls.avoid: Difficult for standard femoral access; plan interventions accordingly

definition.@value: Congenital vascular anomaly where the embryonic sciatic artery persists as the primary lower limb blood supply

medicalCode.description: Other specified congenital malformations of peripheral vascular system

learning_objectives: Describe the embryology of persistent sciatic artery
Recognize clinical presentation and physical exam findings
clinical_pearls: Popliteal pulse with absent femoral pulse = suspect PSA
Up to 50% develop sciatic artery aneurysm
Aneurysm from repetitive trauma of sitting on buttock
Femoral access difficult; plan arterial access carefully
Elective repair recommended for asymptomatic aneurysm
